description: From Middle English domicelle, domicylie, from Middle French domicile and directly from Latin domicilium.

examples: The call to jury duty was sent to my legal domicile; too bad I was on vacation at the time.

entries.meaning: (law) A residence at a particular place accompanied with an intention to remain there for an unlimited time; a residence accepted as a final abode.

verbs.description: domicile (third-person singular simple present domiciles, present participle domiciling, simple past and past participle domiciled)

entries.meaning: To have a domicile in a particular place.
examples: The answer depends on which state he was domiciled in at his death.
